stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a unit of Packed Red Blood Cells (PRBCs). Place the steps in the correct order.
content: First, the nurse must {{Verify Client ID and Blood Type with a second RN}}. Next, obtain a baseline set of {{Vital Signs}}. Then, use a {{18-20 Gauge}} IV catheter and prime the tubing with {{0.9% Normal Saline}} only. The infusion should be started slowly, and the nurse must remain at the bedside for the first {{15 Minutes}}.
options: Verify Client ID and Blood Type with a second RN

rationale.correct: Safe blood administration requires several critical steps: 1. Dual-nurse verification at the bedside prevents fatal ABO incompatibility. 2. Baseline vitals are essential to detect changes indicative of a reaction. 3. Large-bore IV access (18-20g) allows for rapid flow if needed and prevents hemolysis. 4. 0.9% NS is the ONLY compatible fluid (others cause clotting/hemolysis). 5. Staying for 15 minutes ensures immediate detection of acute reactions.
rationale.incorrect: Small gauge catheters like 22g (13) can cause hemolysis if pressure is applied. Temperature (11) is part of vitals, but 'Vital Signs' is the comprehensive requirement. Lactated Ringer's (15) is incompatible with blood products. 30 minutes (17) is too long for the initial observation window; 15 is the standard.
clinicalPearls: Blood must be started within 30 minutes of leaving the blood bank and finished within 4 hours.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember only Normal Saline (0.9% NaCl) can touch blood. Dextrose causes hemolysis, and LR causes clotting (calcium).

mnemonic.title: B-L-O-O-D
mnemonic.expansion: Baseline vitals, Learn ID (2 RNs), Only 0.9% NS, Observe for 15 mins, Done in 4 hours.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Blood
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with blood. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse is preparing to enter an isolation room requiring contact and airborne precautions. Place the PPE in the correct order of donning.
content: First, perform hand hygiene and put on the {{Gown}}. Second, put on the {{N95 Respirator or Mask}}. Third, put on the {{Goggles or Face Shield}}. Finally, put on the {{Gloves}} over the cuffs of the gown.

rationale.correct: The CDC standard sequence for donning PPE is from the least to most likely to become contaminated and from the innermost layer outward: 1. Gown (protects body). 2. Mask/Respirator (protects airways). 3. Goggles/Shield (protects eyes). 4. Gloves (protects hands, goes on last to ensure sterility/cleanliness).
rationale.incorrect: Shoe covers (45) and hair nets (47) are not routine for standard isolation and would be applied at the beginning. Surgical masks (49) are for droplet/standard precautions, whereas N95 (46) is required for airborne. Personal items like a watch (51) should not be worn or would be covered.
clinicalPearls: Doffing PPE is more dangerous than donning and typically follows the alphabetical order: Gloves -> Goggles -> Gown -> Mask.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Donning (putting on) is NOT alphabetical. Doffing (taking off) is close to alphabetical (Gloves, Goggles, Gown, Mask).

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Infection Control
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with infection control. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse needs to mix NPH and Regular insulin in one syringe. Order the steps correctly.
content: First, inject air into the {{NPH (Cloudy)}} vial. Next, inject air into the {{Regular (Clear)}} vial. Then, withdraw the dose from the {{Regular (Clear)}} vial. Finally, withdraw the dose from the {{NPH (Cloudy)}} vial.

rationale.correct: The 'Clear before Cloudy' (RN: Regular before NPH) mnemonic ensures that the rapid-acting clear insulin (Regular) is not contaminated by the long-acting cloudy insulin (NPH). Injecting air into NPH first, then air into Regular, then drawing Regular, and finally drawing NPH allows for single-syringe mixing without contamination.
rationale.incorrect: Lantus (glargine) (79) should NEVER be mixed with any other insulin in the same syringe. Mixing the colors in reverse (Cloudy before Clear) (83, 82) would contaminate the Regular insulin vial with NPH proteins, altering its pharmacological profile.
clinicalPearls: Always rotate the NPH vial gently (do not shake) to mix the suspension before drawing.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Lantus (Glargine) is a 'loner'. It stays in its own syringe and never gets mixed.

mnemonic.title: R-N
mnemonic.expansion: Regular then NPH (Registered Nurse). Clear then Cloudy.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Diabetes
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with diabetes. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: Place the steps of tracheostomy care in the correct order.
content: 1. {{Suction the tracheostomy tube}} if necessary. 2. Remove the old dressing and clean the site with {{Sterile Saline}}. 3. Clean and replace the inner cannula using {{Sterile Technique}}. 4. Change the ties, keeping the old ties in place until the new ones are secure. 5. Apply a new {{Pre-cut Sterile Dressing}}.

rationale.correct: Tracheostomy care priorities: 1. Suctioning first ensures airway patency during the care. 2. Sterile saline is the standard cleansing agent; it is non-irritating to tissue. 3. Handling the inner cannula is a sterile procedure to prevent lower respiratory infection. 4. Pre-cut dressings (fenestrated) are essential because cutting a standard 4x4 gauze produces lint that can be inhaled.
rationale.incorrect: Hydrogen peroxide (113) can damage new granulation tissue and is only used if there is extreme crusting (then rinsed). Clean technique (115) is insufficient for inner cannula care. Moving/cutting cotton-filled gauze (117) creates lint/fibers that are an aspiration hazard. Never deflate the cuff (111) unless specifically ordered during a trial.
clinicalPearls: Check that you can fit two fingers under the tracheostomy ties to ensure they are not too tight.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: NEVER use scissors to cut gauze for a trach. The loose fibers can be aspirated into the lungs. Use pre-cut dressings only.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Respiratory
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with respiratory. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse inserts an indwelling urinary catheter for a female client. Order the procedural steps.
content: Position the client and open the sterile kit. Don sterile gloves. Lubricate the catheter tip. Clean the meatus with antiseptic swabs from {{Front to Back}}. Insert the catheter until {{Urine Flows}}, then advance another 2-3 inches. Inflate the balloon with {{Sterile Water}}. Secure the tubing to the thigh.

rationale.correct: Sterile catheterization steps for a female: 1. Cleaning front to back (top to bottom) prevents the introduction of fecal E. coli into the urethra. 2. Advancing the catheter 2-3 inches *after* urine flow appears ensures the balloon is fully inside the bladder and not trapped in the narrow urethra. 3. Sterile water is used for the balloon; it does not crystallize and obstruct the valve over time.
rationale.incorrect: Back to front (145) cleaning is a major cause of UTIs. Advancing until resistance is felt (147) can cause urethral trauma. Normal saline (149) is avoided for balloons because the salt can crystallize and permanently wedge the balloon in the bladder. Air (150) is used only in specific pediatric or diagnostic catheters.
clinicalPearls: If you accidentally insert the catheter into the vagina, LEAVE IT there as a marker and use a NEW sterile kit/catheter to find the urethra.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Do NOT inflate as soon as you see urine. You must advance further. In women, 2 inches; in men, all the way to the Y-port.

mnemonic.title: W-A-F
mnemonic.expansion: Water for balloon, Advance after flow, Front-to-back cleaning.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Procedures
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with procedures. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse is inserting a nasogastric (NG) tube. Order the steps.
content: Measure the tube from the tip of the nose to the {{Earlobe}}, then to the {{Xiphoid Process}}. Lubricate the tip. Instruct the client to {{Swallow}} as the tube passes the nasopharynx. Verify placement by {{X-ray}}.

rationale.correct: NG tube protocol: 1. The Nose-to-Earlobe-to-Xiphoid (NEX) measurement properly estimates the distance to the stomach. 2. Having the client swallow water or sips of air helps close the epiglottis over the trachea and facilitates entry into the esophagus. 3. X-ray is the ONLY definitive 'gold standard' for verified placement before medications or feedings are initiated.
rationale.incorrect: Measuring to the jaw (178) or umbilicus (180) result in incorrect tube length. Holding the breath (182) is not required and makes swallowing difficult. Auscultation (184) of air bubbles ('whoosh test') is outdated and unreliable for safety verification as air in the lung can sound like air in the stomach.
clinicalPearls: If the client begins coughing, gagging, or turns blue during insertion, pull the tube back or remove it immediately; it is likely in the trachea.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Never pick 'Auscultation' as the best way to verify NG placement. It is unreliable. X-ray is always the silver bullet.

mnemonic.title: N-E-X
mnemonic.expansion: Nose, Earlobe, Xiphoid (The correct measurement path).

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: GI
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with gi. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: Teaching a client with a left leg injury how to use crutches on stairs.
content: Going UP usually requires: 'Good leg goes up directly to heaven'. So, advance the {{Right (Unaffected) Leg}} first. Then advance the {{Crutches and Left Leg}}. Going DOWN usually requires: 'Bad leg goes down to...'. So, advance the {{Crutches and Left Leg}} first. Then advance the {{Right (Unaffected) Leg}}.

rationale.correct: The mnemonic 'Up with the Good, Down with the Bad' ensures stability. UP: The strong leg (Right) moves first to lift the body weight up onto the next step. DOWN: The crutches and weak leg (Left) move down first to create a stable base for the body to descend onto, followed by the strong leg.
rationale.incorrect: Leading up with the affected leg (212) doesn't provide the power needed to lift the center of gravity. Descending with the good leg first (211) would leave the weak leg behind and increase the risk of a fall.
clinicalPearls: When going down stairs, the crutches should be on the step BELOW the patient for maximum support.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Always move the crutches WITH the bad leg. They are a team. The 'good' leg is the leader going up and the follower going down.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Musculoskeletal
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with musculoskeletal. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse assists with chest tube removal. Order the client instructions.
content: Place the client in a {{Semi-Fowler's}} position. Instruct the client to perform the {{Valsalva Maneuver}} (bear down) as the tube is pulled. Immediately apply an {{Occlusive Dressing}}.

rationale.correct: During chest tube removal: 1. Semi-Fowler's allows for lung expansion. 2. The Valsalva Maneuver (bearing down against a closed glottis) increases intrathoracic pressure. This prevents atmospheric air from being 'sucked' into the pleural space while the hole is open. 3. An occlusive dressing (usually petroleum gauze) creates an airtight seal over the site.
rationale.incorrect: Prone (242) is impossible for chest tube care. A simple deep breath (244) actually DECREASES intrathoracic pressure, which could cause a recurrent pneumothorax. Dry gauze (246) is porous and would allow air to enter the pleural space.
clinicalPearls: Obtain a chest X-ray 30-60 minutes after removal to ensure the lung remains fully expanded.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Instructions are: 'Take a breath and BEAR DOWN'. This is Valsalva. Never have them inhale *while* the tube is passing out.

mnemonic.title: B-E-A-R
mnemonic.expansion: Breath in, Exhale against closed glottis, Air stays out, Removal complete.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Respiratory
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with respiratory. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: The nurse changes a central venous catheter dressing. Order the steps.
content: Don a mask and have the client {{Turn Head Away}} from the site. Remove the old dressing carefully. Don {{Sterile Gloves}}. Clean the site with {{Chlorhexidine}} using a back-and-forth friction motion. Allow to dry completely. Apply the new tegaderm.

rationale.correct: Central Line-Associated Bloodstream Infection (CLABSI) prevention: 1. Client turns head away to avoid respiratory droplets falling on the insertion site. 2. Sterile gloves are mandatory for any contact with the site or new dressing. 3. Chlorhexidine is the superior antiseptic for skin antisepsis; the friction scrub and air-drying are critical to its efficacy.
rationale.incorrect: Holding the breath (274) is required for TUBING changes (prevent air embolism) but not for DRESSING changes. Clean gloves (276) are only used for removing the OLD dressing. Alcohol (278) or Betadine (279) are secondary options and lack the long-lasting antimicrobial effect of Chlorhexidine.
clinicalPearls: Scrub the hub with alcohol for at least 15 seconds every time the line is accessed.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: You MUST let the chlorhexidine air-dry completely. Do not fan it or blow on it. The drying time is when the antisepsis happens.

mnemonic.title: C-C-S
mnemonic.expansion: Chlorhexidine, Cover head away, Sterile gloves.

reviewUnits.heading: Advanced Study: Infection Control
reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with infection control. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.

stem: Order the steps for initiating a peripheral IV.
content: Apply the tourniquet 4-6 inches above the site. Clean the site with antiseptic. Anchor the vein. Insert the catheter at a {{10-30 Degree}} angle with bevel up. Observe for {{Blood Return}}. Lower the angle and advance the catheter. Release the {{Tourniquet}}. Connect tubing.

rationale.correct: Peripheral IV success: 1. A shallow 10-30 degree angle is necessary to enter the vein without piercing the posterior wall. 2. Observing for blood return (flashback) confirms the needle is in the vessel. 3. The tourniquet MUST be released before flushing or connecting fluids to prevent high-pressure rupture (blowing) of the vein.
rationale.incorrect: A 45-60 degree angle (307) would likely pierce through the narrow vein. Stopping at resistance (309) doesn't allow for catheter advancement. Releasing the catheter (311) itself before finishing would cause a loss of access.
clinicalPearls: Always choose the most distal vein site first (e.g., hand or lower forearm) to preserve proximal veins for future use.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: If you see a flashback but can't advance, you might be at a valve. Release the tourniquet and try 'floating' it in with a small amount of saline flush.

reviewUnits.body: Focus on the pathophysiology, assessment cues, and priority interventions associated with procedures. Ensure you can distinguish it from similar differential diagnoses.
